results.title: Hoop dreams
results.creator_credit: Steve James, Peter Gilbert, Frederick Marx, Kartemquin Films and KTCA-TV (Television station : Saint Paul, Minn.)
results.brief_description: ‘Hoop Dreams’ follows two star basketball players over five years, beginning when they are just fourteen and heading for high school careers that will make or break their dreams of becoming stars in the NBA. Arthur Agee and William Gates emerge as distinct characters, engaging the audience in an almost heartbreaking degree of emotional identification with the hurdles they both have to overcome. Unlike many sports films that climax with the supreme triumph of victory in the big game, this film challenges the definition of what constitutes winning. Winner of the Audience Award at the Sundance Film Festival in 1994.

results.title: The Hudsucker proxy
results.creator_credit: Joel Coen, Ethan Coen and Warner Bros Pictures
results.brief_description: Norville Barnes is an inexperienced college graduate who finds his first job working in the mail-room of the very profitable Hudsucker Industries. After Hudsucker Industries’ founder and Chairman falls to his tragic death, leaving behind no will and a stunned and panic-stricken board od directors, Vice-President Sidney Messburger sees a brilliant opportunity for taking over the company. He promotes the naive Norville to Company Chairman so as to devalue Hudsucker stocks so that the Board may acquire controlling interests. All doesn’t go according to plan, however when Norville’s new product, the Hula Hoop, is a raging success. Cast includes: Tim Robbins, Jennifer Jason Leigh, Paul Newman, Charles Durning, John Mahoney, Steve Buscemi and Peter Gallagher.

results.title: The Chess player = Le Joueur D'echecs
results.creator_credit: Raymond Bernard, Photoplay, Thames Television and La Societe des Films Historiques
results.brief_description: Based in historical fact, this silent costume drama is set in 1776 and concerns a German engineer at the Viennese court who created a chess-playing automaton to entertain the Empress Maria Theresa and other royalty. Such was the machine’s track record (Napoleon lost a game to it), suspicion grew that a human being was concealed inside. This material allowed Bernard, whose first film was the sumptuous spectacle ‘Le Miracle Des Loups’(‘The Miracle of the Wolves’) (1929), to again demonstrate his pictorial invention and his knack for not letting spectacle swamp his fine cast of actors. Music plays an important part throughout in sustaining the film’s sweep. This restoration, sourced from prints found in Luxembourg, Germany and Holland, revives the atmospheric original score composed by Henri Rabaud, director of the Paris Conservatoire from 1920 to 1941 and a master of orchestration. Cast includes Pierre Blanchar, Charles Dullin, Edith Jehanne and Camille Bert. From the novel by Henry Dupuy-Mazuel, with full orchestral score. This video edition produced by David Gill and Kevin Brownlow. Music performed by the Symphony Orchestra of Radio-Television-Luxembourg. WITH MUSICAL SOUNDTRACK.

results.title: Carla's song
results.creator_credit: Ken Loach, Sally Hibbin, Parallax Pictures, Film Four International, Channel 4 and Bim Distribution
results.brief_description: George (Robert Carlyle) is a bus driver working in Glasgow who has a strong independent streak and has developed a serious crush on one of his regular passengers, a woman from Nicaragua named Carla (Oyanka Cabezas). Carla is occasionally short of money for her fare, so George lets her ride for free; when his boss finds out it is added to his list of insubordinations, and George is fired. George keeps in touch with Carla and discovers that she is actually a refugee from Nicaragua suffering emotional problems that stem from the disappearance and probable death of her boyfriend, a Sandinista supporter who is believed to have been kidnapped by US-backed Contra rebels. The largely apolitical George travels with Carla to Nicaragua at a time when the Contra-rebels are about to launch their final, lethal assault on the Sandinista government.

results.title: The Sinking of the Rainbow Warrior
results.creator_credit: Michael Tuchner, Sam Strangis and Capital Cities
results.brief_description: A docu-drama based on the shocking terrorist attack initiated by the French government on the Greenpeace flagship vessel the Rainbow Warrior. The ship which was the centrepiece of the Greenpeace protest against nuclear testing that was being undertaken by the French in the Pacific, was moored in Auckland in August 1986 when it was blown apart by a bomb blast, killing one of its crew. In this dramatization, Sam Neill and Jon Voight play two polar opposites - a hardbitten cop and a eco-activist, respectively - who team up to track down the bombers uncovering an international conspiracy in the process. Cast also includes Bruno Lawrence and Kerry Fox.

results.title: Tom Jones
results.creator_credit: Tony Richardson and Woodfall Film Productions
results.brief_description: Tom Jones (Albert Finney) is found as a newborn in a wealthy squires bed. The illegitimate child grows into a man attractive to all women who happen to pass him in 18th century rural England. Throughout this comic soap opera of love, family and Bruegelesque debauchery, Tom Jones is certainly put through a lot before the lengthy and irreverent film’s conclusion. The plot follows Tom as he is kicked out of home and travels to London, pursued by the woman he loves. There are plenty of adventures along the way, including much feasting, heaving of breasts, sword fighting and a masked ball, just to name a few. The truth of Jones’ parentage is always in question, he doesn’t even know who his real parents are. None of the hardships faced during Tom’s adventure bother him and it’s not often that the smile leaves his attractive face. Based on the classic novel by Henry Fielding, this precursor to ‘Alvin Purple’ is both satirical and bawdy.

results.title: Sleep my love
results.creator_credit: Douglas Sirk, Ralph Cohn, Charles Rogers, Mary Pickford and Triangle Productions
results.brief_description: In this noir mystery thriller, a wealthy heiress (Claudette Colbert) wakes up hysterical on board a train from New York to Boston with no idea how she got there. When she contacts her husband (Don Ameche), he informs her that she disappeared after threatening him with a gun. On her return he urges her to visit an eminent psychiatrist. Soon it becomes clear that her apparently loving husband is in fact plotting to drive her to insanity then kill her and collect her fortune. Though dismissed by Sirk himself, this is a tautly paced thriller, with Joseph Valentine’s expressionist photography giving rise to a suitably nightmarish evocation of insanity and shifting appearances. Cast also includes Robert Cummings, Rita Johnson and George Coulouris.

results.title: The End of the day = La Fin du jour
results.creator_credit: Julien Duvivier, Regina Film and Filmsonar a Epinay
results.brief_description: This comedy focuses on the lives and relationships between elderly thespians living in an actors’ retirement home. The home is almost bankrupt and so the actors must support themselves. The residents include a faded sex symbol, an intellectual actor who kept a great distance between himself and the audience, and a depressed thespian who tries to conceal the fact that he was only an understudy. Cast includes Louis Jouvet, Michel Simon, Madeleine Ozeray and Victor Francen. In French.

results.title: The Human beast = La Bete humaine
results.creator_credit: Jean Renoir and Paris Film Productions
results.brief_description: Although Renoir was a pioneer of location shooting and the use of non-professionals in feature films, his films resist easy classification. “La Bete Humaine” is no exception. Relocated in the 1930s, Renoir invests Zola’s story of a man apparently driven by forces outside his control with both careful observation of the working class milieu and a passionate and lyrical poetry which goes beyond Zola’s naturalism. Inspired by the novel by Emile Zola. Cast includes Jean Gabin and Simone Simon. In French with no subtitles.

results.title: The Lacemaker = La Dentelliere
results.creator_credit: Claude Goretta, Yves Gasser, Yves Peyrot, Citel Films, Filmproduktion Janus and Action Films
results.brief_description: Pomme works as a hairdresser and lives with her protective mother in Paris. She goes on a holiday to the seaside town of Cabourg with a more worldly friend. There she forms a relationship with Francois, a young student, and they decide to live together in Paris. Social differences soon emerge. While Francois is garrulously intellectual, Pomme is reserved, incapable of communicating with Francois and his friends but maintaining a mysterious inner radiance. Goretta has described his film as “a genre painting” in narrative form and it is constructed in a series of brief fragmentary scenes which form a picture without evident narrative connections. With its narrative ellipses - eloquent silences and observation of Pomme’s mysterious inner life - Goretta’s film resembles Bresson’s “Une Femme Douce”. Cast includes Isabelle Huppert, Yves Benneyton, Florence Giorgetti, and Anne-Marie Duringer. Based on the novel by Pascal Laine. In French with English subtitles.
